item.title: How Not to Invest in the Bond Market
item.description: Investors poured billions into long-term U.S. government funds last year. Right on cue, the market tanked—again.

item.title: Stock Futures Slip, Oil Gyrates After Israel Strikes Iran
item.description: The strikes jolted prices for stocks, bonds, currencies and commodities, but the moves quickly abated as the limited scope of the assault became clear.

item.title: The Headache at the End of the Costco Gold Rush
item.description: Selling gold bars takes more time and money than stocks, bonds or crypto.

item.title: Banks Believe They Are Well-Prepared for Commercial Real Estate Fallout
item.description: Banks have built up substantial reserves against office loans going bad.

item.title: A Century-Old Lending Lifeline for Troubled Banks Has a Major Flaw. The Fed Wants to Fix It.
item.description: Borrowing from the discount window carries a stigma officials hope to reduce.

item.title: Netflix Dealt With the Freeloaders. Its Next Act Will Be Tougher.
item.description: The decision to stop reporting subscriber numbers will put a greater focus on revenue growth—and advertising.

item.title: America's Cigarette Market Is Up for Grabs
item.description: Philip Morris will soon be able to sell its most successful smoke-free product in the U.S., setting up a battle with its former parent company Altria.

item.title: Asia Markets Fall After Israeli Strike on Iran
item.description: Stock markets in Asia fell while safe-haven assets such as U.S. Treasurys, the yen and the Swiss franc rose sharply after Israel launched a retaliatory strike against Iran early Friday.

item.title: They Bet Against the Dollar. Now They're Paying the Price.
item.description: The dollar recently hit a 34-year high against the yen, sending ripples through global markets.

item.title: Grayscale's Once-Mighty Fund Is Bleeding Bitcoin
item.description: The asset manager has resisted a significant fee cut, betting that rising bitcoin prices will continue to buoy its fortunes.

item.title: Treasury Yields Rise, S&P 500 Extends April Slide
item.description: Stocks mostly slumped Thursday as investors digested a range of corporate earnings including a better-than-expected report from Alaska Air.

item.title: Chip Giant TSMC Offers Reassurance---and a Warning
item.description: The chip industry is recovering more slowly than expected from the inventory glut of 2023 but the semiconductor investments required for the rapid growth of artificial intelligence are on track.

item.title: For Tesla, India Represents Big Promise---and Some Peril
item.description: A factory in India would be a significant risk—but maybe one worth taking.

item.title: Pension Funds Are Pulling Hundreds of Billions From Stocks
item.description: Stock portfolios at large pension funds had a blockbuster run. Now, managers are cashing out and shifting money into bonds.

item.title: China Pledges to Steady Yuan as Asian Currencies Come Under Pressure
item.description: China’s central bank reiterated its commitment to a stable yuan, joining the chorus of Asian officials concerned about weakening regional currencies.

item.title: Bitcoin's Halving Is Coming. Miners Are Looking for New Ways to Make Money.
item.description: Crypto-industry companies turn to artificial intelligence to diversify.

item.title: S&P 500 Falls for Fourth Straight Session on Fading Hopes for Interest-Rate Cuts
item.description: The index’s losing streak is its longest since the first week of 2024.

item.title: Heirs Get More Time to Keep Their Money in Inherited Retirement Accounts
item.description: The Internal Revenue Service postponed required withdrawals from many inherited accounts through 2024.

item.title: Americans Throw Away Up to $68 Million in Coins a Year. Here Is Where It All Ends Up.
item.description: So much change ends up in the trash that one company is digging them up for profit.

item.title: U.S. Crude Oil Supplies Rise More Than Expected
item.description: Weekly commercial crude storage grew by 2.7 million barrels to 460 million barrels, while analysts predicted an increase of 600,00 barrels.
